raw_text:
Cheaper chip for mobiles
 
 A mobile phone chip which combines a modem and a computer processor on one bit of silicon instead of two could make phones cheaper and more powerful.
 
 The specially-designed chip, developed by Texas Instruments, could drive down the cost of making mobiles capable of 3D gaming and 30-frame-a-second video. Currently, rich multimedia features tend to be on more expensive handsets. The technology, OMAP-Vox, is being tested by firms in Europe and Asia and could appear by the end of the year. Texas, which makes computer chips for more than half the world's mobile phones, said it was keen to make multimedia functions like video and gaming more affordable. "We're going to drive them down into meat-and-potatoes phones that have the largest market share," said Doug Rasor, a marketing vice president at Texas. The chip also uses much less power than conventional chips, said Texas, which means less strain on mobile battery life.
 
 More than 50 million people own a mobile in the UK, but mobile operators are keen to encourage people to move onto more sophisticated handsets that can do more. Texas is keen to cash in on the third generation (3G) of mobile technology, which offers high-speed networks for video streaming and other multimedia functions. But it faces stiff competition from the likes of Intel which is also looking to provide better chips for high-end mobiles.
 
 Competition to get people using 3G mobiles will grow in the next year as almost all of the UK's operators have now launched third generation networks. A recent survey by Sony Ericsson predicted that the number of 3G handsets sold in 2005 would double from 2004 to account for 10% of all phones sold. Many consumers are still to be convinced though. A further recent survey said that only 4% of mobile owners were thinking of upgrading to 3G phones. Many said they were confused about the different ways to pay for phones and the vast array of features most have onboard.
 
 But there will be continued demand for better chips as the industry continues to develop new standards and future networks. Earlier in January, NTT DoCoMo and Vodafone joined forces to develop the next generation of high-speed networks, known as "super 3G", intended to be 10 times faster than 3G services. The first stage of development is to be completed by 2007, but no date has been set for a commercial launch The newly-designed OMAP-Vox chip set was announced ahead of the start of a major mobile industry conference, 3GSM, which takes place in Cannes, France this week.
llama3.2:1b: A new chip developed by Texas Instruments combines modem and processor on one silicon bit to make phones cheaper and more powerful, potentially driving down costs for multimedia features like video and gaming.
The technology is being tested in Europe and Asia, with potential commercial launch expected in the end of 2005.
The chip uses less power than conventional chips, reducing battery strain on mobile devices.
llama3.2:3b: A new mobile phone chip combines modem and processor on one bit of silicon, potentially making phones cheaper and more powerful.
Developed by Texas Instruments, OMAP-Vox is being tested and could be available by the end of the year.
The technology aims to make multimedia features like video and gaming more affordable for mass market handsets.
gemma2:2b: Texas Instruments has developed a new chip, OMAP-Vox, that combines a modem and computer processor into one silicon bit.
This could make mobile phones cheaper and more powerful, enabling them to run high-end applications like gaming and video streaming.
The chip is being tested in Europe and Asia and may be available by the end of the year.
Texas Instruments aims to use this technology to make multimedia features affordable across a wider range of mobile phones.
As 3G networks become more widespread, competition for better chips will increase as new standards are developed.
Despite the potential of 3G, many consumers remain hesitant to upgrade to newer handsets due to confusion about pricing and feature complexity.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A new mobile chip designed to integrate a modem and processor on one bit of silicon could make phones more powerful and affordable.
The special chip is being tested by firms in Europe and Asia, with Texas Instruments making computer chips for most mobiles.
It uses less power than conventional chips, reducing strain on battery life.
Many consumers are still unsure about 3G upgrades, but the industry is developing new standards and networks to meet demand.
qwen2.5:1.5b: A new Texas Instruments chip combines modem and processor into one to make cheaper and more powerful mobile phones capable of high-quality multimedia features like 3D gaming and 30-frame-a-second video.

This technology aims to drive down the cost of rich-media functions currently reserved for expensive handsets, which will benefit both existing and future 3G operators aiming to tap into a larger market with affordable devices featuring robust multimedia capabilities.
qwen2.5:3b: A specially-designed OMAP-Vox chip developed by Texas Instruments combines a modem and computer processor on one silicon bit, potentially making mobile phones cheaper and more powerful with features like 3D gaming and 30-frame-a-second video.
The technology is being tested internationally and could be available by year-end.
This chip uses less power than conventional chips, enhancing battery life.
It aims to reduce the cost of sophisticated multimedia functions in affordable handsets to gain market share for Texas Instruments, which manufactures chips for over half the world’s mobile phones.
However, it faces competition from Intel's high-end mobile chip offerings.
Despite UK users already owning 50 million mobiles and interest growing for 3G technology, only a small percentage of consumers (4%) are considering upgrading to 3G phones.
Future development towards super-3G networks continues despite the industry’s ongoing innovation in new standards and future network speeds.

Texas Instruments has developed an OMAP-Vox, creating a specialized chip for 3D gaming and video streaming capabilities.
The chip uses less power than conventional chips and is expected to drive down mobile phone costs in the long run.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
Cheaper chip for mobiles  
A cheaper chip that combines modems and computers on one silicon bit instead of two could make phones more affordable and powerful.
Texas Instruments developed the OMAP-Vox chip, which is being tested by European and Asian firms.
The technology aims to reduce costs for 3D gaming and high 30-frame-a-second video, while using much less power than conventional chips.
Texas emphasized that it would drive more expensive multimedia features like video and gaming into "meat-and-potatoes" phones with large market share.
The chip also uses much less power than conventional chips, meaning lower battery strain.
With a third-generation (3G) network expected next year, the industry is in growth mode.
Competitions from Intel are limiting market share until this year's 3GSM conference.
Surveys suggest increased demand for 3G handsets but confusion about payment methods and features remains.
tinyllama:1.1b: During a mobile phone industry event, Texas Instruments revealed that they are designing a specialized chip that could significantly reduce the cost of making more affordable and powerful mobile phones.
The specially-designed chip is called OMAP-Vox, which combines a modem and a computer processor on one bit of silicon instead of two.
The technology developed by Texas Instruments allows for lower power consumption and greater multimedia capabilities, such as video and gaming, to be driven down in mobile phones.
This makes them more affordable while retaining their advanced features.

Although the demand is still low for 3G phone models, with a growing number of operators launching 3G networks, the potential benefits of high-speed networks will continue to encourage developers to create better chips.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Mobile Phones with Cheaper Chip: A New Technology by Texas Instruments is expected to make handsets more powerful and affordable.
This chip combines a modem and a computer processor on one bit of silicon instead of two.
Texas Instruments is working with several companies in Europe and Asia to develop the technology.
The cost-effective chip could drive down the price of high-end mobiles capable of 3D gaming, 30-frame-a-second video, and more advanced multimedia features.
Currently, rich multimedia functions tend to be on expensive handsets, but this new technology could make them more affordable.
The chip also uses less power than conventional chips, which means it will be more efficient for the user and for the environment.
Over 50 million people in the UK own mobile phones, but mobile operators are keen to encourage users to upgrade to more sophisticated devices that can do more.
Texas is excited about the potential of this technology, as they aim to capitalize on the growth opportunities presented by the third-generation (3G) mobile networks.
The launch of new 3G handsets is expected to increase sales in the next year, with almost all UK operators having launched third-generation networks.
However, only a small percentage of consumers are upgrading to these high-speed devices.
This underscores the need for better chips that can handle more advanced features and work on lower cost handsets.
A recent survey by Sony Ericsson predicted that the number of 3G handsets sold in 2005 would double from 2004, while only 4% of mobile owners were thinking of upgrading to 3G phones.
phi:2.7b: Texas Instruments has developed a new chip that combines a modem and computer processor on one silicon bit, potentially making phones cheaper and more powerful by allowing for 3D gaming and 30-frame-per-second video.
This technology is being tested and could appear by the end of the year.
The company hopes to drive down the cost of multimedia functions like video and gaming in order to reach a wider market share.
Texas' new chip uses less power than conventional chips, meaning less strain on mobile battery life.
While there are currently more expensive handsets with these features, competition is growing as almost all UK operators have launched third generation networks.
This will drive demand for better chips as the industry continues to develop new standards and future networks.
The first stage of development for a faster network is set to be completed in 2007, but no commercial launch date has been set yet.
orca-mini:3b: A cheaper and more powerful mobile phone chip is being developed by Texas Instruments, combining a modem and a computer processor on one bit of silicon instead of two.
The chip, called OMAP-Vox, could drive down the cost of mobile phones with rich multimedia features such as gaming and 30-frame-a-second video.
Its power efficiency and smaller size make it suitable for use in more efficient handsets.
Texas Instruments hopes to reduce the price of high-end mobile phones by offering better performance at a lower cost.
However, it faces competition from Intel, which is also developing advanced chips for high-end mobiles.
Many consumers are still unsure about 3G networks and their needs, but demand for better chips will continue as the industry develops new standards and future networks.

Texas Instruments' OMAP-Vox tested, may appear by end of year.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Texas Instruments has developed a special chip for mobile phones called OMAP-Vox, which combines a modem and a computer processor on one piece of silicon, reducing costs and increasing power efficiency.
This technology could make phones more affordable and capable of 3D gaming and high-quality video.
Texas aims to bring multimedia functions like video and gaming to "meat-and-potatoes" phones with the largest market share.
The OMAP-Vox chip is being tested by European and Asian companies and may be available by the end of the year.
As mobile operators encourage people to upgrade to more sophisticated handsets, there will still be demand for better chips as new standards and future networks are developed.
stablelm2:1.6b: A new chip called OMAP-Vox, developed by Texas Instruments, could make mobile phones cheaper and more powerful by combining a modem and computer processor on one piece of silicon instead of two.
It's being tested by companies in Europe and Asia and may appear by the end of 2011.
The chip uses less power than conventional chips, making it better for mobile battery life.
Texas wants to make multimedia functions like video and gaming more affordable across different types of phones with the largest market share.

Competition for people to use 3G mobiles will grow as all UK operators have launched third-generation networks, but there will still be demand for better chips in the industry as standards and future networks continue to develop.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Texas Instruments has developed a new mobile chip, OMAP-Vox, combining a modem and a computer processor onto one silicon piece.
This innovation aims to reduce the cost of producing high-performance smartphones capable of 3D gaming and 30-frame-per-second video, making multimedia features more accessible to mass-market phones.
The chip uses less power than conventional chips, extending battery life.
Texas Instruments, which manufactures chips for over half the world's mobile phones, is eager to promote these advanced functions through 3G networks.
While the UK has over 50 million mobile users, many are yet to upgrade due to confusion about pricing and features.
However, with the launch of nearly all UK operators' third-generation networks and the development of "super 3G" by NTT DoCoMo and Vodafone, demand for enhanced smartphones is expected to rise.
The newly announced OMAP-Vox chip will be showcased at the upcoming 3GSM conference in Cannes, France.
chatgpt-4o-latest: A new mobile phone chip developed by Texas Instruments combines a modem and processor on a single silicon chip, potentially making phones cheaper and more powerful.
The OMAP-Vox chip could lower costs for 3D gaming and high-quality video, making multimedia features more affordable.
It also consumes less power, improving battery life.
Texas aims to expand these features to mainstream phones but faces competition from Intel and others.
With the rise of 3G networks, demand for better chips is growing, though consumer adoption remains slow due to confusion over pricing and features.
Meanwhile, companies like NTT DoCoMo and Vodafone are working on "super 3G" networks, expected to be 10 times faster than current 3G services.
The OMAP-Vox chip was announced ahead of the 3GSM mobile industry conference in Cannes.
